greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Sum_{1<=k<=n, k is not a divisor of n and k is not coprime to n} k.
comment: This function can be used to prove no p^k is perfect or multi-perfect.
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = 0 if and only if n = 1, 4 or a prime. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 31 2004
example: There are three integers that satisfy this definition for n = 12, namely 8, 9 and 10. These sum to 27, hence a(12) = 27.
mathematica: Table[n(n + 1)/2 + 1 - EulerPhi[n] * n/2 - DivisorSigma[1, n], {n, 2, 65}] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 31 2004 *)
Table[Sum[k * Boole[Not[Divisible[n, k]]] * Boole[GCD[n, k] > 1], {k, n - 1}], {n, 65}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 02 2014 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=n*(n + 1 - eulerphi(n))\2 + 1 - sigma(n) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 02 2014
(MAGMA) [0] cat [1 + n*(n+1)/2 - SumOfDivisors(n) - n*EulerPhi(n)/2: n in [2..70]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Nov 03 2014
results.author: _Jon Perry_, Jan 17 2002
ext: Offset corrected to 1 by _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 05 2014
